    Is the Bluesky-Shine Wearing Off Already? | cmdr-nova@internet:~$
    Is the Bluesky-Shine Wearing Off Already?

    Author:

    Published: 25 Nov 2024


    Like I do, I‚Äôve been semi-tracking and participating in the boom of the Bluesky social network, even though it‚Äôs not decentralized, currently, in any meaningful way. In my own experience, I‚Äôm having a hard time finding ‚Äúmy people.‚Äù I don‚Äôt even know if I have a ‚Äúmy people‚Äù anymore. But, that aside, from within my feed, I‚Äôm watching and seeing reports of constant troll attacks, some stating, ‚ÄúYeah, I don‚Äôt like it here actually.‚Äù So, let‚Äôs talk about Mastodon, again, maybe?

    Over the past week or so, I‚Äôve seen posts from people talking about, and have experienced personally, Kiwifarms trolls following people in some inane scare tactic. If you don‚Äôt know what KF is, it‚Äôs an extremely niche stalker website full of pyschopaths whose only hobbies are documenting and stalking people online, with mostly fabricated information.

    It‚Äôs been giving people a bit of a sour taste in their mouths in regards to sticking to this, basically, brand new platform.

    To add insult to injury, it seems now, as of today, that trolls are going around sending users extremely graphic and violent images of death.

    I want to note, that Mastodon is not perfect by any stretch. But this is where true decentralization comes in, and saves the day.

    If you‚Äôre on a community run instance on Mastodon (or other AcitivityPub software), or your own, you don‚Äôt have to put up with this kind of behavior. You don‚Äôt have to play whack-a-mole with every new account that pops up. You can just ‚Ä¶ block out the instance that is acting as the source of this behavior.

    Of course, Mastodon does have its own issues. There are a lot of basic FOSS guys, and do they love to either give you bad advice, unprompted advice, or scold you for doing things your way.

    I‚Äôm showing you this, in order to be fully transparent about what you may encounter on Mastodon, and how we would deal with this. For context, I have Python scripts running on a VPS, and one of them sends random images from top posts across different subreddits, to Mastodon. Some of them are NSFW, some of them aren‚Äôt. Either way, I also have it tagging each post with hashtags I wanted to have on it, like #python (because it‚Äôs running on python!)

    This isn‚Äôt favorable to some. Simply using your mute button isn‚Äôt enough. Some people have to tell you that they don‚Äôt like that you‚Äôre using your software, your instance, and your social media to do whatever you want, your own way.

    And that‚Äôs fine!

    We can send him into the ether, never to be heard from again. Or, we can block the entirety of the instance he‚Äôs coming from.

    In this example, I‚Äôm not sure what kind of behavior usually comes out of chaos.social, but we can check it to see if this is the attitude of more of its users, or if this guy is an outlier.

    So, chaos.social looks pretty run-of-the-mill and likely not a massive source of basic FOSS guys trying to dictate to random people on the fediverse how they should post. We won‚Äôt have to block the whole entire instance. But! Since blocking single users is probably something everyone‚Äôs already familiar with, and doesn‚Äôt take a lot to figure out how to do, let me just show you how one would block the whole instance, if in fact it was a bed of trolls and hats of the arse.

    If you click that little pea-pod under a user‚Äôs post, and look down, you can see the option to, as a singular user, block the entire domain.

    What this will do, is evaporate all posts coming from that server, entirely. You will never see them again, unless you unblock them.

    In the instance that a server happens to be a bed of trolls, maybe trolls who are sending people threats, being assholes, or generally gross, this is an awesome feature.

    Now, I get it. The perfect social media experience would be never having to interact with, or deal with trolls, or people with a superiority complex. Unfortunately, that‚Äôs not the world we currently live in. When choosing a Mastodon server, or a server of any kind that‚Äôs connected to ActivityPub, it is very important to make sure that server has rules, and guidelines for behavior.

    I understand that this is, for some, an incredible extra step to just signing up, and posting. But it‚Äôs essential. It ‚Ä¶ will really help avoid situations down the line where you‚Äôre suddenly asking the entire fediverse, ‚ÄúHey, why are there so many trolls???‚Äù and then everyone‚Äôs pointing to your instance, that has no rules.

    If you decide Bluesky isn‚Äôt the right place for you, don‚Äôt go back to Twitter. Give the ‚ÄúLinux of social media‚Äù a chance, and maybe you won‚Äôt be disappointed. Mileage may vary, but there really is something to using software that is highly customizable, near completely user owned, and run.



    tags: bluesky  socialmedia  mastodon 
    mkultra.monster is independent, in that it is written, developed, and maintained by one person. Written, developed, and maintained, not for scrapers, bots, scammers, algorithms, or grifters: But for people to follow and read, just like the way it used to be, back in the golden age of the internet.
